history.content:
I took it with Gahl a couple of years ago.

I didn't find it useful. It taught a bit of R and a bit of stats; no linguistics (which was what I really wanted; the course just uses textual and linguistics-related data sets, without discussing any linguistics). The R part should be self-learnable by any CS major, and the stats part is mostly a subset of what an intro stats course (e.g. AP Stats or Stats 2/20/21) covers, with ANOVA as the only major exception that I can recall.

There was no course website.

If you want to take this course because you're interested in the quantitative methods part, then yes, I would suggest taking a stats course instead.

If you're interested in analyzing linguistics data, I don't know of a good course that does this (other than NLP-oriented courses like CS288/Info256).

It's Quantative Methods in Linguistics.

Would I be better off taking a stats course?
